etymologies: Old English; earliest use found in King Alfred (c848–899), king of the West Saxons and of the Anglo-Saxons. From of + down, with the literal meaning ‘from the hill’

definitions: To a lower place or position; downward, down; towards the earth. Frequently with verbs of motion, often those signifying descent, as fall, sink, kneel, etc.
Figurative and in figurative contexts. During, over the course of, or after (a period of time); throughout (the course of time).
